canonical_explanation.text: Elements can be broadly classified into metals and non-metals based on their physical and chemical properties. Metals are typically lustrous (shiny), malleable (can be beaten into sheets), ductile (can be drawn into wires), good conductors of heat and electricity, and sonorous (produce a ringing sound when struck). Non-metals are generally brittle, non-lustrous, poor conductors, and non-sonorous. Chemically, metals react with oxygen to form basic oxides, react with acids to produce hydrogen gas, and can displace less reactive metals from their salt solutions. Non-metals react with oxygen to form acidic or neutral oxides. The reactivity series arranges metals in order of their reactivity, with potassium and sodium being the most reactive and gold and platinum being the least reactive. A more reactive metal can displace a less reactive metal from its salt solution in a displacement reaction.
rules: Metals are lustrous, malleable, ductile, good conductors of heat and electricity, and sonorous.
Non-metals are generally brittle, non-lustrous, and poor conductors of heat and electricity.
Mercury is an exception: it is a liquid metal at room temperature.
Iodine is an exception: it is a lustrous non-metal.
Metal + Oxygen → Metal oxide (basic in nature).
Non-metal + Oxygen → Non-metal oxide (acidic or neutral).
A more reactive metal displaces a less reactive metal from its salt solution.
The reactivity series lists metals from most reactive to least reactive.
Gold and platinum are least reactive metals; potassium and sodium are most reactive.

questions.question_text: Which property of metals allows them to be beaten into thin sheets?
questions.explanation_correct: Malleability is the property that allows metals to be beaten or hammered into thin sheets without breaking. For example, aluminium and gold can be beaten into very thin sheets called foils.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ductility is the property of being drawn into wires, not sheets. Sonority refers to the ringing sound when struck. Conductivity is the ability to conduct heat and electricity. Malleability specifically refers to the ability to be hammered into sheets.

questions.question_text: Which of the following metals is liquid at room temperature?
questions.explanation_correct: Mercury is the only metal that exists as a liquid at room temperature. It has a very low melting point of about -39 degrees Celsius, which is why it is used in thermometers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Iron, aluminium, and copper are all solid metals at room temperature. Mercury is unique among metals because it is liquid at room temperature due to its very low melting point.

questions.question_text: Which property of metals means they produce a ringing sound when struck?
questions.explanation_correct: Sonority is the property of metals that allows them to produce a ringing sound when struck. This is why metals are used in making bells, cymbals, and other musical instruments.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lustre refers to the shiny appearance of metals. Malleability is the ability to be hammered into sheets. Ductility is the ability to be drawn into wires. Sonority specifically refers to the ringing or resonating sound produced when a metal is struck.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a physical property of non-metals?

options.text: They are good conductors of electricity

questions.explanation_correct: Non-metals are generally brittle, meaning they break easily when hammered or stretched. Unlike metals, they cannot be beaten into sheets or drawn into wires. They are also poor conductors and non-sonorous.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Good conductivity, malleability, and sonority are properties of metals, not non-metals. Non-metals are characteristically brittle, non-lustrous, and poor conductors of heat and electricity.

questions.question_text: Which non-metal is an exception because it has a lustrous appearance?
questions.explanation_correct: Iodine is a non-metal that has a lustrous (shiny) appearance, which is unusual for non-metals. Despite this metallic appearance, iodine has all other properties of non-metals — it is brittle and a poor conductor.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sulphur, carbon (in most forms), and phosphorus are non-lustrous non-metals. Iodine is the notable exception among non-metals as it displays a shiny, lustrous appearance similar to metals.

questions.question_text: Why is copper used for making electrical wires?

options.text: Copper is an excellent conductor of electricity and is ductile

questions.explanation_correct: Copper is used for electrical wires because it is an excellent conductor of electricity (allowing current to flow easily) and is ductile (can be drawn into thin wires). These two properties together make it ideal for wiring.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While copper has many properties, the key reasons for electrical wires are its excellent electrical conductivity and ductility. Copper is not the hardest metal and is not completely non-reactive. Its combination of conductivity and ability to be drawn into wires makes it the best choice.

questions.question_text: What is produced when a metal reacts with an acid?
questions.explanation_correct: When a metal reacts with an acid, it produces a salt and hydrogen gas. For example, zinc + hydrochloric acid produces zinc chloride (salt) + hydrogen gas. The hydrogen gas can be tested with a burning splint — it burns with a 'pop' sound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Metal + acid does not produce oxide and water, hydroxide and oxygen, or salt and carbon dioxide. The correct products are a salt (formed from the metal and the acid) and hydrogen gas, which can be identified by the 'pop' sound test.

questions.question_text: What type of oxide is formed when a metal reacts with oxygen?
questions.explanation_correct: When metals react with oxygen, they form metal oxides which are basic in nature. For example, magnesium burns in oxygen to form magnesium oxide (MgO), which is a basic oxide that turns red litmus blue.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Non-metals form acidic oxides, not metals. Metals form basic oxides when they react with oxygen. For example, sodium oxide and magnesium oxide are basic oxides that turn red litmus paper blue when dissolved in water.

questions.question_text: What type of oxide do non-metals form when they react with oxygen?
questions.explanation_correct: Non-metals react with oxygen to form acidic or neutral oxides. For example, sulphur burns in oxygen to form sulphur dioxide (acidic oxide), while carbon monoxide is a neutral oxide.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Non-metals do not form basic oxides — that is a property of metals. Non-metals form either acidic oxides (like sulphur dioxide, carbon dioxide) or neutral oxides (like carbon monoxide, water).

questions.question_text: In the reactivity series, which of the following metals is the MOST reactive?
questions.explanation_correct: Potassium is the most reactive metal among the options. In the reactivity series, potassium is at the top, meaning it reacts vigorously with water, acids, and oxygen. Gold is the least reactive (at the bottom).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gold is the least reactive metal and is at the bottom of the reactivity series. Iron and copper are in the middle. Potassium sits at the top of the reactivity series, making it the most reactive metal listed.

questions.question_text: What is a displacement reaction?

options.text: A reaction where two elements combine
A reaction where a more reactive metal replaces a less reactive metal from its salt solution
A reaction where a compound breaks down
A reaction between an acid and a base

questions.explanation_correct: A displacement reaction occurs when a more reactive metal displaces (replaces) a less reactive metal from its salt solution. For example, if iron is placed in copper sulphate solution, iron displaces copper because iron is more reactive than copper.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A combination reaction involves elements combining. A decomposition reaction involves compounds breaking down. An acid-base reaction is neutralisation. A displacement reaction specifically involves a more reactive metal taking the place of a less reactive metal in a solution.

questions.question_text: When an iron nail is placed in copper sulphate solution, the solution changes colour from blue to green. Why?

options.text: Iron displaces copper from the solution, forming iron sulphate (green)

questions.explanation_correct: Iron is more reactive than copper, so iron displaces copper from copper sulphate solution. The blue copper sulphate is converted to green iron sulphate, and the displaced copper deposits on the iron nail as a brownish layer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The colour change is not due to iron dissolving, evaporation, or the nail changing colour. It is a displacement reaction: iron (more reactive) displaces copper (less reactive) from its salt solution, forming green iron sulphate and depositing copper metal on the nail.

questions.question_text: Which metal is commonly used in the construction of buildings and bridges?
questions.explanation_correct: Iron (in the form of steel) is commonly used in construction of buildings and bridges because it is very strong, hard, and relatively inexpensive. It can bear heavy loads and is readily available.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gold is too expensive for construction. Mercury is a liquid metal. Sodium is too reactive and soft. Iron, especially in the form of steel, provides the strength and durability needed for buildings and bridges.

questions.question_text: Which non-metal is essential for respiration in living organisms?
questions.explanation_correct: Oxygen is the non-metal essential for respiration. Living organisms inhale oxygen which helps break down glucose in cells to release energy, carbon dioxide, and water. Without oxygen, aerobic respiration cannot occur.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While nitrogen is abundant in air and carbon is present in living things, oxygen is the specific non-metal required for respiration. Sulphur is not involved in the breathing process. Oxygen is breathed in to provide energy through cellular respiration.

questions.question_text: A student strikes two different objects with a hammer. Object A produces a ringing sound while object B breaks into pieces. What can be concluded?

options.text: Object A is a non-metal and Object B is a metal
Object A is a metal (sonorous) and Object B is a non-metal (brittle)

questions.explanation_correct: Object A is a metal because it is sonorous (produces a ringing sound when struck). Object B is a non-metal because it is brittle (breaks into pieces when struck). These are distinguishing physical properties of metals and non-metals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If both were metals, neither would break easily. If both were non-metals, neither would ring. The ringing sound (sonority) is a characteristic of metals, while brittleness (breaking on impact) is characteristic of non-metals.

questions.question_text: Sodium reacts vigorously with water. What does this tell us about sodium's position in the reactivity series?

options.text: Sodium is at the bottom of the reactivity series
Sodium is in the middle of the reactivity series
Sodium is near the top of the reactivity series (highly reactive)
Sodium does not appear in the reactivity series

questions.explanation_correct: Sodium's vigorous reaction with water indicates it is highly reactive. In the reactivity series, sodium is placed near the top, along with potassium and lithium. Metals at the top react vigorously even with cold water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Metals at the bottom of the reactivity series (like gold and platinum) do not react with water at all. Sodium's vigorous reaction clearly places it near the top of the series where the most reactive metals are found.

questions.question_text: When magnesium ribbon burns in air, it produces a white powder. This white powder is:
questions.explanation_correct: When magnesium ribbon burns in air (reacts with oxygen), it produces a bright white light and forms magnesium oxide, a white powder. Magnesium oxide is a basic oxide that turns red litmus blue when dissolved in water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Burning in air means the magnesium is reacting with oxygen, so the product is magnesium oxide. Magnesium chloride would form with hydrochloric acid, magnesium sulphate with sulphuric acid, and magnesium carbonate with carbonic acid.

questions.question_text: Sulphur dioxide dissolves in water to form an acidic solution. This shows that sulphur is a:
questions.explanation_correct: Sulphur is a non-metal. When non-metals burn in oxygen, they form non-metal oxides which are acidic in nature. Sulphur dioxide dissolves in water to form sulphurous acid, which turns blue litmus red.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Metals form basic oxides, not acidic ones. The fact that sulphur dioxide forms an acidic solution confirms that sulphur is a non-metal, since non-metal oxides are acidic or neutral in nature.

questions.question_text: A silver spoon is placed in copper sulphate solution, but no reaction occurs. What does this tell us?

options.text: Silver is more reactive than copper
Silver is less reactive than copper
Silver and copper have equal reactivity

questions.explanation_correct: Since no displacement reaction occurs, silver is less reactive than copper. A less reactive metal cannot displace a more reactive metal from its salt solution. Only a more reactive metal can displace a less reactive one.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If silver were more reactive than copper, it would displace copper from the solution. The absence of reaction proves that silver is less reactive than copper in the reactivity series. Copper sulphate is quite reactive with metals more reactive than copper.

questions.question_text: Why is aluminium used for making cooking utensils?

options.text: Aluminium is a good conductor of heat and is lightweight
Aluminium does not react with anything

questions.explanation_correct: Aluminium is used for cooking utensils because it is a good conductor of heat (heats food quickly and evenly), is lightweight (easy to handle), and is resistant to corrosion due to a thin oxide layer that forms on its surface.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Aluminium is light, not heavy. It does react with acids and bases. It is not necessarily the cheapest metal. Its key advantages for cookware are good heat conductivity, light weight, and corrosion resistance.

questions.question_text: Give two examples each of metals that are: (a) good conductors of electricity, and (b) poor conductors of heat. Which option correctly lists these?
questions.explanation_correct: Copper and silver are among the best conductors of electricity. Lead and mercury are metals that are relatively poor conductors of heat compared to other metals. This shows that while most metals are good conductors, some are better than others.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sulphur, phosphorus, carbon, and iodine are non-metals, not metals. Gold and silver are excellent conductors, not poor ones. Copper and silver are top electrical conductors, while lead and mercury are the poorest heat conductors among common metals.

questions.question_text: When zinc granules are added to dilute hydrochloric acid, a gas is evolved that burns with a 'pop' sound. The gas is:
questions.explanation_correct: When zinc reacts with dilute hydrochloric acid, hydrogen gas is evolved along with the formation of zinc chloride. Hydrogen gas burns with a characteristic 'pop' sound when a burning matchstick is brought near it. This is the standard test for hydrogen gas.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Oxygen supports combustion but does not pop. Carbon dioxide extinguishes flames. Nitrogen is inert. Hydrogen is the gas produced when metals react with acids, and its characteristic test is the 'pop' sound when ignited.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following metals in decreasing order of reactivity: Iron, Gold, Zinc, Sodium.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct decreasing order of reactivity is Sodium > Zinc > Iron > Gold. Sodium is highly reactive (reacts vigorously with water), zinc and iron are moderately reactive, and gold is the least reactive (it is found in free state in nature).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gold is the least reactive metal, not the most. Sodium is the most reactive among these four metals. The reactivity series places them as Sodium > Zinc > Iron > Gold, from most to least reactive.

questions.question_text: Which of the following non-metals is essential for the formation of proteins and DNA in living organisms?
questions.explanation_correct: Nitrogen is an essential non-metal found in proteins, amino acids, and DNA/RNA. It makes up about 78% of the atmosphere and is crucial for plant growth (in fertilisers) and the structure of biological molecules.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While sulphur is present in some proteins, nitrogen is the key element in all proteins and nucleic acids (DNA and RNA). Chlorine and bromine are halogens not primarily associated with protein or DNA structure.

questions.question_text: A student tests an unknown element and finds: it is hard, shiny, conducts electricity, and makes a ringing sound when hit. The element is most likely a:
questions.explanation_correct: The element shows all characteristic properties of metals: hard, lustrous (shiny), conducts electricity, and sonorous (makes a ringing sound). All these properties together strongly suggest it is a metal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Non-metals are generally brittle, non-lustrous, and poor conductors. Noble gases are gaseous elements. Compounds are not elements. The combination of lustre, conductivity, and sonority clearly indicates a metal.

questions.question_text: Why are gold and platinum used to make jewellery?

options.text: They are lustrous, malleable, and do not corrode easily
They are good conductors of heat

questions.explanation_correct: Gold and platinum are used for jewellery because they are lustrous (shiny and attractive), highly malleable (can be shaped into intricate designs), and are at the bottom of the reactivity series, meaning they do not corrode or tarnish easily.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gold and platinum are among the most expensive metals. They are not the hardest metals. While they conduct heat, that is not relevant to jewellery. Their lustre, malleability, and resistance to corrosion make them perfect for jewellery.

questions.question_text: Iron articles rust when exposed to moist air. Rusting involves the reaction of iron with:
questions.explanation_correct: Rusting of iron requires both oxygen and moisture (water). Iron reacts with oxygen in the presence of water to form hydrated iron oxide (rust). If either oxygen or moisture is absent, rusting does not occur.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Iron does not rust in dry air (no moisture) or in oxygen-free water (no oxygen). Both oxygen and moisture must be present simultaneously for rust to form. This is why iron articles stored in dry places or coated with oil do not rust.

questions.question_text: If copper is placed in iron sulphate solution, will a reaction occur? Give reason.

options.text: Yes, because copper is more reactive than iron
No, because copper is less reactive than iron
Yes, because all metals react with salt solutions
No, because iron sulphate is unreactive

questions.explanation_correct: No reaction will occur because copper is less reactive than iron in the reactivity series. A displacement reaction only happens when a more reactive metal is placed in the salt solution of a less reactive metal. Since copper is below iron, it cannot displace iron.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Copper is less reactive than iron, not more. Not all metals react with all salt solutions — only more reactive metals displace less reactive ones. Iron sulphate is reactive with metals above iron in the series. Copper being below iron means no displacement occurs.

questions.question_text: Which property of metals allows them to be drawn into thin wires?
questions.explanation_correct: Ductility is the property that allows metals to be drawn into thin wires. Copper and aluminium are highly ductile metals and are therefore used for making electrical wires.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sonority is the ringing sound property. Malleability is the ability to be beaten into sheets. Lustre is the shiny appearance. Ductility specifically refers to the ability to be pulled or drawn into thin wires.

questions.question_text: Carbon exists in different forms. Which form of carbon is the hardest natural substance?
questions.explanation_correct: Diamond is the hardest naturally occurring substance known. It is a form (allotrope) of carbon where each carbon atom is bonded to four other carbon atoms in a rigid three-dimensional structure, making it extremely hard.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Graphite is soft and slippery (used in pencils). Charcoal and coal are impure forms of carbon. Diamond is the allotrope of carbon that is the hardest natural substance, used for cutting and drilling.

questions.question_text: All metals are solid at room temperature.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Mercury is a metal that is liquid at room temperature. It is the only metal that exists in liquid state at normal temperatures, making it an exception to the general rule that metals are solids.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While most metals are solid at room temperature, mercury is the exception. Mercury has a very low melting point of about -39 degrees Celsius and exists as a shiny silvery liquid at room temperature.

questions.question_text: When metals react with oxygen, they form acidic oxides.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. When metals react with oxygen, they form basic oxides, not acidic oxides. It is non-metals that form acidic oxides when they react with oxygen. For example, magnesium oxide is basic, while sulphur dioxide is acidic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Metal oxides are basic in nature, not acidic. Non-metal oxides are acidic. For example, sodium oxide dissolved in water forms a basic solution (sodium hydroxide), while sulphur dioxide dissolved in water forms an acidic solution (sulphurous acid).

questions.question_text: A less reactive metal can displace a more reactive metal from its salt solution.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Only a more reactive metal can displace a less reactive metal from its salt solution. For example, iron (more reactive) can displace copper (less reactive) from copper sulphate solution, but copper cannot displace iron.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Displacement reactions only work in one direction: more reactive displaces less reactive. A less reactive metal lacks the chemical drive to push out a more reactive metal from its salt. This principle is the basis of the reactivity series.

questions.question_text: Graphite is a non-metal that is a good conductor of electricity.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Graphite is an allotrope of carbon (a non-metal) that can conduct electricity. This is an exception to the general rule that non-metals are poor conductors. Graphite's layered structure allows electrons to move freely between layers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Although non-metals are generally poor conductors, graphite is a well-known exception. It is used in electrodes and pencil leads. Its unique layered structure gives it the ability to conduct electricity despite being a form of carbon, a non-metal.

questions.question_text: Gold is found in nature in its free state because it is the most reactive metal.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Gold is found in nature in its free state because it is the LEAST reactive metal, not the most reactive. Being at the bottom of the reactivity series, gold does not react easily with other elements, so it remains uncombined in nature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gold is found in free state precisely because it is unreactive, not because it is reactive. Highly reactive metals like sodium and potassium are never found free in nature — they always exist as compounds because they react readily with other elements.

questions.question_text: When zinc reacts with dilute sulphuric acid, zinc sulphate and hydrogen gas are formed.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. When zinc (a moderately reactive metal) reacts with dilute sulphuric acid, it forms zinc sulphate (a salt) and hydrogen gas is evolved. The hydrogen gas can be identified by the 'pop' sound test.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reaction between zinc and dilute sulphuric acid does produce zinc sulphate and hydrogen gas. This is a typical metal-acid reaction: Metal + Acid produces Salt + Hydrogen gas.

questions.question_text: The property of metals by which they can be beaten into thin sheets is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Malleability is the property of metals that allows them to be beaten or hammered into thin sheets. Gold and silver are the most malleable metals. Aluminium foil used in kitchens is an example of malleability.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'malleability'. This property is different from ductility (ability to be drawn into wires). Malleability specifically refers to the ability to be hammered or rolled into thin sheets.

questions.question_text: The only metal that is liquid at room temperature is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Mercury is the only metal that exists as a liquid at room temperature. Its melting point is about -39 degrees Celsius, well below room temperature. It is a shiny silvery liquid used in thermometers and barometers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'mercury'. All other metals are solid at room temperature. Mercury's uniquely low melting point makes it the only liquid metal under normal conditions.

questions.question_text: When metals react with acids, ___ gas is evolved.
questions.explanation_correct: When metals react with acids, hydrogen gas is evolved. For example, zinc reacting with hydrochloric acid produces zinc chloride and hydrogen gas. The hydrogen gas burns with a characteristic 'pop' sound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'hydrogen'. The general reaction is: Metal + Acid produces Salt + Hydrogen. The evolved hydrogen gas can be tested by bringing a burning matchstick near it, which produces a 'pop' sound.

questions.question_text: In a displacement reaction, a ___ reactive metal displaces a less reactive metal from its salt solution.
questions.explanation_correct: In a displacement reaction, a more reactive metal displaces a less reactive metal from its salt solution. For example, zinc (more reactive) displaces copper (less reactive) from copper sulphate solution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'more'. Only a metal higher in the reactivity series (more reactive) can displace a metal lower in the series (less reactive) from its salt solution.

questions.question_text: The property of metals by which they can be drawn into thin wires is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Ductility is the property that allows metals to be drawn or pulled into thin wires. Copper and aluminium are highly ductile metals, which is why they are used for making electrical wires.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'ductility'. This is different from malleability (beaten into sheets). Ductility specifically means the ability to be stretched into thin wires without breaking.

questions.question_text: Which non-metal is used in fertilisers to promote plant growth?
questions.explanation_correct: Nitrogen is the primary non-metal used in fertilisers (such as urea and ammonium nitrate) to promote plant growth. Plants need nitrogen for producing proteins, chlorophyll, and nucleic acids essential for their growth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While phosphorus is also used in some fertilisers, nitrogen is the most widely used and essential non-metal in fertilisers. Nitrogen-based fertilisers like urea are the most common agricultural fertilisers worldwide.

questions.question_text: Which of the following metals does NOT react with dilute hydrochloric acid?
questions.explanation_correct: Gold does not react with dilute hydrochloric acid because it is at the bottom of the reactivity series and is extremely unreactive. Zinc, iron, and magnesium are all reactive enough to displace hydrogen from dilute acids.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Zinc, iron, and magnesium all react with dilute hydrochloric acid to produce salts and hydrogen gas. Gold, being the least reactive metal in the reactivity series, does not react with dilute acids.

questions.question_text: Which non-metal is used in water purification?
questions.explanation_correct: Chlorine is a non-metal widely used in water purification. It acts as a disinfectant, killing harmful bacteria and other microorganisms present in water, making it safe for drinking.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While carbon (as activated charcoal) can filter water, chlorine is the primary non-metal specifically used as a chemical disinfectant in water purification to kill disease-causing microorganisms.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is true about the physical properties of metals and non-metals?

options.text: All metals are hard and all non-metals are soft
Metals are generally good conductors while non-metals are generally poor conductors
Metals cannot be cut with a knife

questions.explanation_correct: Metals are generally good conductors of heat and electricity, while non-metals are generally poor conductors. This is the most accurate generalisation. There are exceptions: sodium is a soft metal, diamond is a hard non-metal, and graphite conducts electricity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Not all metals are hard (sodium is soft) and not all non-metals are soft (diamond is very hard). Non-metals can be solids (sulphur), liquids (bromine), or gases (oxygen). Some metals like sodium and potassium can be cut with a knife.

questions.question_text: Which of the following displacement reactions will occur?
questions.explanation_correct: Zinc + Copper sulphate will show a displacement reaction because zinc is more reactive than copper. Zinc will displace copper from the solution, forming zinc sulphate and depositing copper metal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Copper cannot displace zinc (zinc is more reactive). Silver cannot displace copper (copper is more reactive than silver). Gold cannot displace iron (iron is more reactive than gold). Only zinc (more reactive) can displace copper (less reactive).

questions.question_text: Non-metal oxides are ___ in nature when dissolved in water.
questions.explanation_correct: Non-metal oxides are acidic in nature when dissolved in water. For example, sulphur dioxide dissolves in water to form sulphurous acid, and carbon dioxide dissolves to form carbonic acid. These solutions turn blue litmus red.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'acidic'. Non-metal oxides form acidic solutions in water, unlike metal oxides which form basic solutions. Some non-metal oxides like carbon monoxide are neutral, but most are acidic.

questions.question_text: Why is iron coated with zinc to prevent rusting? This process is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Coating iron with a layer of zinc to prevent rusting is called galvanisation. The zinc coating protects the iron from coming in contact with moisture and oxygen, thereby preventing the formation of rust (iron oxide).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electroplating is coating with a metal using electricity. Alloying is mixing metals. Smelting is extracting metal from ore. Galvanisation specifically refers to coating iron or steel with zinc to prevent rust.

questions.question_text: Why do sodium and potassium metals need to be stored in kerosene oil?

options.text: To prevent them from reacting with air and moisture

questions.explanation_correct: Sodium and potassium are highly reactive metals that react vigorously with air (oxygen) and moisture (water). Storing them in kerosene oil prevents contact with air and moisture, keeping them safe from dangerous reactions that produce heat and flames.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Storing in kerosene has nothing to do with appearance, warmth, or weight. The purpose is safety — sodium and potassium are so reactive that they catch fire when exposed to air and react violently with water, making kerosene storage essential.

questions.question_text: The shiny appearance of metals is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The shiny appearance of metals is called lustre (or luster). Metals like gold, silver, and copper have a bright lustre which makes them attractive. Freshly cut metals show the best lustre before they tarnish.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer is 'lustre'. This is one of the key physical properties used to identify metals. The shiny surface of metals reflects light, giving them their characteristic lustrous appearance.
